Grokking ExPLAIND: Unifying Model, Data, and Training Attribution to Study Model Behavior

Florian Eichin1, Yupei Du2, Philipp Mondorf1, Barbara Plank1, and Michael A. Hedderich1
1 MaiNLP, Center for Information and Language Processing, LMU Munich, Germany
and Munich Center for Machine Learning (MCML)
2 Utrecht University, the Netherlands
1{f.eichin,p.mondorf,bplank,hedderich}@lmu.de, 2y.du@uu.nl
Abstract

Post-hoc interpretability methods typically attribute a model’s behavior to its components, data, or training trajectory in isolation. This leads to explanations that lack a unified view and may miss key interactions. While combining existing methods or applying them at different training stages offers broader insights, these approaches usually lack theoretical support. In this work, we present ExPLAIND, a unified framework that integrates all three perspectives. First, we generalize recent work on gradient path kernels, which reformulate models trained by gradient descent as a kernel machine, to more realistic training settings. Empirically, we find that both a CNN and a Transformer model are replicated accurately by this reformulation. Second, we derive novel parameter- and step-wise influence scores from the kernel feature maps. We show their effectiveness in parameter pruning that is comparable to existing methods, reinforcing their value for model component attribution. Finally, jointly interpreting model components and data over the training process, we leverage ExPLAIND to analyze a Transformer that exhibits Grokking. Among other things, our findings support previously proposed stages of Grokking, while refining the final phase as one of alignment of input embeddings and final layers around a representation pipeline learned after the memorization phase. Overall, ExPLAIND provides a theoretically grounded, unified framework to interpret model behavior and training dynamics.

1 Introduction

Understanding the latent mechanisms of deep neural networks remains one of the central challenges in machine learning [39, 37, 52]. As models become increasingly complex, interpretability has become an increasingly crucial tool — not just for debugging or improving transparency, but for building trust, ensuring fairness, and guiding further development [11]. Much of the recent progress in interpretability has focused on attributing a model’s behavior to one of three main factors: its parameters or components, the data it was trained on, or the dynamics of the training process itself.

However, these approaches are often applied in isolation. This fragmentation limits our understanding, leaving important interactions unexplored. Explanations focused on model components may ignore the influence of individual training examples or how these components evolved during optimization. Data-centric explanations can overlook how different parts of the model internalize those examples. And while recent work has begun to probe training dynamics [29, 44, 35] — especially in phenomena like Grokking, where generalization suddenly emerges late in training — these insights remain only loosely connected to analyses of model architecture or input data.

In this work, we present Exact Path-Level Attribution Integrating Network and Data (ExPLAIND), a unified interpretability framework that integrates all three attribution perspectives: model components, data, and training dynamics. Our approach builds on and extends the Exact Path Kernel (EPK, [7]) view of gradient-based learning, which reformulates models trained via gradient descent as kernel machines defined over the trajectory of their training. While this perspective offers a powerful theoretical grounding, prior formulations were restricted to standard gradient descent settings. We generalize the EPK framework to encompass more realistic training regimes incorporating first- and second-order gradient estimates, weight decay, dynamic learning rates, and mini-batching. We empirically demonstrate that this kernel reformulation accurately represents both a CNN and a Transformer model. Building on this foundation, we derive novel influence scores that quantify how individual parameters and training steps contribute to the model predictions. These scores not only offer new insights into model component attribution but also prove effective for model compression via parameter pruning, performing comparably to established methods.

We apply ExPLAIND to a Transformer model known to exhibit Grokking, a training dynamic where the model initially memorizes the training set before generalizing to the test set after extended training. Our unified lens reveals nuanced interactions between data, parameters, and optimization steps. Notably, we identify a previously unreported alignment phase at the end of training, where input embeddings and final layers align around a representation pipeline learned in preceeding training steps. This insight challenges and refines the prevailing three-phase narrative of Grokking—memorization, circuit formation, and cleanup [31] suggesting instead a progression through memorization, representation pipeline formation, and embedding-decoder alignment.

Through these contributions, ExPLAIND offers a theoretically grounded, empirically validated, and practically useful framework for interpreting modern machine learning models in a holistic manner.

2 Related work

Post-hoc interpretability.

Post-hoc interpretability methodology generally aims to attribute either the input features [38, 28, 8, 51], the training data [33, 15, 9, 19, 3, 25, 14, 22], or model components [43, 49, 47, 30, 2, 42, 32, 12, 37] to model behavior [52]. However, many approaches lack a unified theoretical grounding [24, 40, 11, 5, 4] and can trade faithfulness for plausibility [21]. Recent work has expanded interpretability to the temporal dimension, aiming to attribute model behavior across training dynamics, for example by applying probing [1] over different intermediate model checkpoints to attribute different learning phases [29]. Others use circuit finding methodology to identify the causally relevant components for the model’s predictions [44, 35]. Yet, such approaches typically treat each training step independently, lacking a theoretical framework for integrating changes in model behavior over time. Other techniques such as dataset cartography [41] or training trajectory analysis [50] offer empirical insight but do not formally connect training dynamics and model components to the model predictions. Furthermore, previous data attribution methodology usually aims to understand the influence of a sample as a mean over infinite training runs. In contrast, our method provides exact attribution scores for a given model instance.

Gradient based methods.

Gradient path kernels [10] reformulate a model trained by gradient descent to an equivalent kernel machine. Bell et al. [7] generalize this to an exact equivalence deriving the Exact Path Kernel (EPK, [7]), but do not extend their formulation and empirical investigation to learning scenarios that include gradient updates based on first- and second-order estimates, weight decay, dynamic learning rates, and mini-batching. Central to the EPK reformulation is the comparison of the gradients of training samples with those of the test sample at every step of training by a dot product. This work is therefore connected to the Neural Tangent Kernel [20], of which the EPK is a generalization over the training trajectory, and which has been influential in studying neural networks. TracIn [36] also measures dot-product gradient similarities across the trajectory for data attribution, but does not use the kernel as implied by the EPK and thus lacks this theoretical connection to model predictions. Furthermore, their focus inherently lacks the model component perspective.

Grokking.

Grokking, coined by Power et al. [34], refers to a training phenomenon where models initially overfit but eventually generalize after prolonged training. Liu et al. [26] expanded this study to a broader suite of tasks and model architectures, providing a systematic characterization of Grokking’s occurrence. More recent work [48, 53, 18] explores the implicit reasoning capabilities that arise during Grokking, the critical role of dataset size, and their connection to the double descent phenomenon, respectively. Our work suggests a reinterpretation of the previously proposed stages of Grokking by connecting perspectives on the model components and its training data.

3 Methodology

3.1 An Exact Kernel Equivalence for Non-Standard Gradient Descent

Unlike traditional post-hoc methods that ignore optimizer-induced parameter paths [38, 1, 28, 22], the EPK leverages the iterative nature of gradient-based training to encode model behavior into a kernel function, which scores the influence of each training point on a prediction. In its basic form, assuming vanilla gradient descent (GD), their central result can be written as follows.

Theorem 1 (EPK Representation for GD, Bell et al. [7]).

Previously, the EPK has been studied for standard GD, where the training trajectory admits this decomposition. However, modern deep learning relies on adaptive optimizers such as AdamW [27], which maintains exponential moving averages of the first- and second-order gradient moments. The inclusion of weight decay, learning rate schedules and mini-batch training further complicates the trajectory. As Bell et al. [6] remark, the EPK can be extended to all combinations of these settings. We will now explicitly derive this representation which faithfully captures the compounded effects of these settings over the course of training for AdamW and GD with Momentum.

Sketch of proof. We mainly follow the arguments of Theorem 1. Remark.

We can use the above result to derive the EPK reformulation for a training procedure of GD with momentum and weight decay. The key difference is the absence of the second order term and that the regularization term moves into the momentum term, which results in the reformulation of the respective term. For momentum β𝛽\betaitalic_β and learning rates αssubscript𝛼𝑠\alpha_{s}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we then have 𝐫s=αs⁢∑i=0s−1βs−i⁢θi⁢(0)subscript𝐫𝑠subscript𝛼𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑖0𝑠1superscript𝛽𝑠𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖0\mathbf{r}_{s}=\alpha_{s}\sum_{i=0}^{s-1}\beta^{s-i}\theta_{i}(0)bold_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s - italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 ).

3.2 Integrating Model Component Attribution

Taking a step further, we want to extend the EPK to link model component attribution with the impact of the training trajectory and data with respect to model predictions. We do this by mapping the overall influence of each step on the parameter level. Note that the kernel reformulation in Equation 2 is composed of sums over dot products introduced by the loss (which we will call kernel term) and the regularization term. Similarity from the model’s perspective.

Our parameter-wise influence scores also enable the analysis of similarity of two predictions by comparing their scores with respect to different parts of the model. We propose to do this by measuring the cosine similarity. Let’s assume we want to analyse the similarity of two predictions of samples x𝑥xitalic_x and x′superscript𝑥′x^{\prime}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with respect to a subset of parameters ΘΘ\Thetaroman_Θ that defines said part of the model. We can use the previously introduced sample-wise component influence vectors to compute:

Evaluated over a set of samples, we can thereby study the geometry of the model’s predictions and thus build and test hypotheses about its behavior and internal representations.

Training step influence on the predictions.

To attribute different training steps, ExPLAIND’s influence scores can be accumulated over different model parts (as is implied by Equation 3) and also the training and test instances. Furthermore, note that our reformulation contains a term introduced by regularization that contributes to the updates of the prediction in each step. Like the kernel term, this term contains a dot product of the test feature map and the model parameters and can thus be leveraged in an analogous way to get parameter-wise and step-wise influence scores of the regularization term on the prediction. Furthermore, we view the absolute influence scores as a measure of importance of the respective components, training samples, or training step for the given prediction of x𝑥xitalic_x. To investigate the relative contributions of the kernel and regularization terms, we furthermore propose the accumulated parameter-wise difference of absolute influences:

D⁢(Θ):=∑θ∈Θ(𝚿s⁢(θ)−𝚿sr⁢e⁢g⁢(θ))assign𝐷Θsubscript𝜃Θsubscript𝚿𝑠𝜃subscriptsuperscript𝚿𝑟𝑒𝑔𝑠𝜃D(\Theta):=\sum_{\theta\in\Theta}\left(\mathbf{\Psi}_{s}(\theta)-\mathbf{\Psi}% ^{reg}_{s}(\theta)\right)italic_D ( roman_Θ ) := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ ∈ roman_Θ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_Ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) - bold_Ψ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_g end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) ) (9)

Remark.

Note that all previous derivations are based on accumulating parts of the kernel and regularization matrices implied by Corollary 1.1. ExPLAIND is not restricted to these forms of accumulations and thus other ways of interpreting model behavior are possible through the lens of the EPK influence scores. Depending on the desired level of granularity, this has implications for how efficiently one can implement their computations. For example, for influence scores accumulated over the training data, the space- and time-complexity is equivalent to a single training run. Materializing all scores up to parameter level is expensive however, as the memory complexity alone is in 𝒪⁢(N⁢D⁢M⁢O)𝒪𝑁𝐷𝑀𝑂\mathcal{O}(NDMO)caligraphic_O ( italic_N italic_D italic_M italic_O ) for N𝑁Nitalic_N training steps, D𝐷Ditalic_D parameters, M𝑀Mitalic_M training samples, and O𝑂Oitalic_O dimensions.

4 Experiments and Results

Our experiments are split into two parts111all implementations are available at https://github.com/mainlp/explaind. First, we validate our EPK reformulation on the realistic optimization scenarios described above. We then validate our interpretation of the kernel influence scores by using them as importance scores in a model parameter pruning experiment. Second, we apply ExPLAIND and the previously derived influence scores to study the Grokking phenomenon, integrating model components, data, and training trajectory into our explanations in Section 4.2.

We validate our derivations on a vision and text model: a CNN model, namely ResNet9 [17], and a single-layer Transformer. For the former we train on the CIFAR-2 partition of CIFAR-10 containing images of cats and dogs. We train this model using mini-batch GD with momentum and weight decay (details in Appendix C.1). For the latter, the Transformer model is trained to solve a modulo addition task where the samples consist of tokens [a][+][b][mod113=][a][+][b][\mathrm{mod}113=][ italic_a ] [ + ] [ italic_b ] [ mod113 = ] from which the correct result has to be predicted. This model was proposed by [45] and used as an object to study Grokking in other recent work [18, 31]. We train our model with AdamW [27] and weight decay (details in Appendix C.2) and plot the training statistics in Figure 2. For the second part of our experiments in Section 4.2, we further analyse this Transformer model to study the Grokking phenomenon.

4.1 Validation of the Kernel Equivalence

The EPK accurately replicates both models.

To validate the theoretical results in Section 3.1, we compute the reformulations from Corollary 1.1 for the CNN and Transformer models, respectively. We ablate the number of integration steps in the test feature map ϕtestsuperscriptitalic-ϕtest\phi^{\text{test}}italic_ϕ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT test end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and summarize the results in Figure 1 on the right. Here, using 100 integration steps provides an accurate approximation for both models, reproducing 100% of their classification decisions. Furthermore, the output distributions closely match those of the original models, indicated by near-zero KL divergences. We therefore keep this number of integral steps for the rest of this study.

ExPLAIND influence scores enable model compression.

To study the applicability of our parameter importance scores, we carry out a series of pruning experiments on the CNN model, ranking each parameter θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ by its kernel importance score ΨS⁢(θ)subscriptΨ𝑆𝜃\Psi_{S}(\theta)roman_Ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ). For a fraction c𝑐citalic_c and number of parameters D𝐷Ditalic_D, we only keep the TOP-c⁢D𝑐𝐷cDitalic_c italic_D parameters and set the rest to zero. To retain the model’s ability to predict, we do not prune the output layer. To contextualize our results, we compare them against an implementation of Li et al.’s pruning method proposed to compress CNN models [23], which is based on an iterative pruning procedure in which the model is retrained in each step after pruning weights by magnitude importance. Note that this comparison is to validate that our scores find meaningful influence scores and do not aim to frame ExPLAIND as a SOTA pruning method. As shown in Figure 1, we find that our approach performs competitively against the baseline. Our approach outperforms the baseline on sparsity levels from 70% to 99%. Furthermore, our score-based, training-free pruning replicates the original model more closely than the baseline as is evidenced by the much lower KL divergences over all levels of sparsity. This underlines that our influence scores are indeed able to accurately quantify the influence of the parameters on the model’s predictions.

4.2 Investigating Grokking through the lenses provided by ExPLAIND

We will now focus on employing ExPLAIND to study the Transformer model, which exhibits Grokking. The high level of generalization that is characteristic for Grokking has been explained by multiple learning stages, which Nanda et al. [31] define as (1) memorization of the training data, (2) circuit formation, in which the model learns a robust mechanism and thus generalizes, and (3) cleanup, during which the regularization "removes" memorization components. Other evidence also suggests that Grokking is introduced by a specific balance between model size, dataset size, and regularization [18]. We thus argue that the study of Grokking should include attributions to model components, dataset, and the effects of regularization, all of which the ExPLAIND framework unifies. As shown on the left in Figure 2, the Transformer exhibits Grokking: first, it shows a sharp drop in the training loss until around epoch 500 and, subsequently, perfect training accuracy. At the same time, the test loss increases and starts to decrease again as the regularization term increases. Lastly, a generalization phase leads to perfect test performance at step 1,939, after which we terminate training.

Tracing the influences of regularization.

Observing the EPK over the course of training, we now study the influence of the kernel term Ψs⁢(Θ)subscriptΨ𝑠Θ\Psi_{s}(\Theta)roman_Ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Θ ) and the influence of the regularization term Ψsr⁢e⁢g⁢(Θ)subscriptsuperscriptΨ𝑟𝑒𝑔𝑠Θ\Psi^{reg}_{s}(\Theta)roman_Ψ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r italic_e italic_g end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Θ ). Notably, the absolute influences of the kernel and regularization terms plotted in the top middle of Figure 2 follow a close trajectory, with the kernel terms influence on the prediction being slightly higher for most of the procedure. They increase monotonically starting from around epoch 200 when the memorization phase begins. This trend is reversed at around training step 1,700, when both curves reach their respective peaks and then decline over the last 239 epochs of the training — suggesting that the final generalization phase is governed by a higher relative influence of regularization. On the layer level shown in the top right plot of Figure 2, the first memorization phase coincides with a peak in relative kernel influence D⁢(Θ)𝐷ΘD(\Theta)italic_D ( roman_Θ ) on the decoder layer, followed by a sharp dominance of the regularization influence on the embedding layer. Both layers then follow the same trajectory with high relative regularization influence, indicating that regularizing inefficient memorization circuits is especially important in the embedding and decoder layers.

Grokking phases on the kernel level.

Focusing on the bottom right plot in Figure 2, we observe that the kernel influences of the layers Ψs⁢(Θm⁢o⁢d⁢e⁢l)subscriptΨ𝑠subscriptΘ𝑚𝑜𝑑𝑒𝑙\Psi_{s}(\Theta_{model})roman_Ψ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_Θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m italic_o italic_d italic_e italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) differ greatly. Overall, the decoder has the highest influence with two peaks around steps 400 and 500 respectively, which is evidence that the decoder is most influential in the memorization phase. Notably, the second peak of the decoder influence is preceeded by peaks of the attention and linear layers, suggesting a single alternation between fitting the decoder and the intermediate layers marking the beginning of the circuit formation phase. The embedding layer only starts to influence the prediction during this phase, explaining its high relative regularization influence. However, it then proceeeds to increase slightly over the rest of the training while all other influences decrease in the second half of the procedure. Together with the decoder layer, and — to a lesser extent, the pre-final second linear layer — the final generalization phase’s influence on the prediction is dominated by input and output layers. This indicates that the rapid increase in test performance of the model can be explained by a simultaneous alignment of the input embeddings and decoder around the representations of the intermediate layers, whose influence is relatively low during this phase. Connecting it to Huang et al.’s [18] notion of efficiency, this might be the point where the intermediate representation pipeline is robust enough for memorization circuits to become obsolete which in turn are thus "cleaned up" as Nanda et al. [31] argue.

Emergence of cyclic patterns in the kernel.

To study the effects of the training data on the predictions during the different learning phases, we plot the slices of the kernel matrix summed over the output dimensions in Figure 3 for different training stages. Because the decoder layer is by far the most influential for the prediction, we chose to only plot its respective kernel (others found in Appendix E.1). Over all training stages, each training sample seems to have a global effect on the predictions, as indicated by the vertical bands in the kernel matrices. Later, this pattern is interpolated with off-diagonals that emerge after the memorization phase. They become more pronounced throughout training and are most apparent in the final stage. Here, the off-diagonals transition from a mostly uniform pattern to distinct concentrations along the main diagonal and off-diagonals corresponding to correct modulo results. This indicates that the influence of training samples on model predictions is governed by a cyclic distance between the training and test sums. Directly after the memorization phase, the cycles are of high frequency of about 2, i.e. the influence is high for training samples whose label difference with the predicted sample is a multiple of 2. Throughout the memorization phase, this cyclic geometry of the training continuously moves towards an interpolation of lower frequencies.

The model learns a generalizable data geometry.

To geometrically understand the roles of the different layers and their evolution over training, we plot their parameter-level similarities at different training stages in Figure 5. Here, we note a similar emergence of cyclic patterns, especially in the higher layers of the model. This suggests that the model indeed learns to represent the samples in a space where similarity is approximately a cosine of frequency 113. We test this hypothesis by fitting a Lasso regression to the similarity matrix accumulated over epochs 1850 to 1900 of the decoder, where we take as input features all cosines and sines of the pairwise differences of frequencies 2 to 113. The result is shown in Appendix E.3 and indeed confirms our qualitative observation with the coefficient of the cosine of frequency 113 being by far the largest. Furthermore, we note that in the final model this representation emerges only in the attention decoders, suggesting that the model first needs to combine the two input numbers and then proceeds to refining the cyclic geometry observed in higher layers. These observation agree with the findings of Nanda et al. [31], who find that neurons in the linear layers are computing combinations different cosines and sines. As ExPLAIND reveals, the fine-grained, neuron-level mechanisms that they describe result in a cyclic global pattern that is simple to interpret and the result of a continuous refinement over the circuit finding phase.

Grokking is a progression of representation learning and alignment.

The previous findings suggest that the final Grokking stage’s change in predictions might be a consequence of an alignment of the embeddings and the decoder, with the second linear layer also playing a smaller role. We test this hypothesis by swapping grokked layers into intermediate model checkpoints and plot the results in Figure 4. We find that these described outer layers of the model are able to improve the predictions of non-final checkpoints, while other combinations decrease performance. This indicates that the final versions of these layers are able to perform well even around an intermediate representation pipeline that is not yet fully generalized, i.e. is not able to produce a perfect separation of the data along a cosine of frequency 113. Comparing the confusion matrices of the of swapped and original checkpoints in Figure 4 (c) to (f), we find that systematic, cyclic error patterns on the off-diagonals that the checkpoints exhibit are greatly reduced after swapping the final model’s outer layers. Furthermore, we test our hypothesis by training around this grokked pipeline, initializing the remaining weights randomly. We plot the training and test accuracy in Figure 4 and find that this initialization results in instant Grokking over the first 200 training steps, without exhibiting a prior memorization phase. This suggests, that alignment around the intermediate representation pipeline is indeed the most efficient once it has formed to a sufficient extent. We test this scenario for other combinations of layers (plotted in Appendix E.2) and find that even only using the attention layer leads to this phenomenon. Starting from layers taken from earlier iterations, we also note the same rapid generalization, though to percentages slightly lower than 100% the earlier the checkpoint. This suggests, that, to a minor degree, the representation pipeline gets refined in the final stages of training.

5 Discussion and Conclusion

Our study on Grokking reveals a novel perspective on the model’s learning phases. In particular, we uncover the alignment phase characterized by the high relative influence of regularization on these layers following a phase of representation formation. In grokked models, further training may serve to refine and re-use rather than build representations. Once a robust latent structure has formed, generalization may emerge through alignment of input and output layers, raising questions about optimal training strategies. This supports a view of fine-tuning as a mechanism for selecting among capabilities learned during pretraining in larger models by aligning the vocabulary space [13, 16].

Limitations.

Our study is limited to small toy models and tasks. Also, the ExPLAIND framework is focused on weight-level analysis and does not provide a mechanistic or causal explanation in the activation space. Furthermore, as discussed in Section 3, computing our influence scores has quadratic complexity. Nevertheless, for studies on larger models, runtimes can still be as low as a single training run depending on which level of granularity the scores are computed and implementation. Due to the computational cost of applying ExPLAIND to the extent shown (details in Appendix C.3), we were not able to confirm our results over multiple training runs.

Future Work.

It remains to be shown, whether ExPLAIND in general and the Grokking results specifically scale to larger models and more complex tasks. Besides, it should be investigated whether ExPLAIND can be utilized to interpret activation-level phenomena, e.g. by mapping parameter-wise scores to their respective neurons or employing guided backpropagation for input attribution. Furthermore, our observations imply that the alignment phase is accompanied by a large relative influence of regularization in the outer model parts. This raises the question, whether dynamic regularization schemes targeting these parts could improve training. We also observed that attribution of model behavior to data and model components varies over the training course, with critical patterns emerging at different stages. Future interpretability methodology should be designed to better surface these critical stages, ensuring key patterns are not obscured by uninformative contributions or diluted through aggregation in global explanations.

In summary, ExPLAIND offers a unified framework that bridges model components, data, and training dynamics, addressing a gap in post-hoc interpretability. ExPLAIND leverages recent gradient path theory, incorporating realistic gradient descent optimization schemes and novel parameter-wise influence scores. We validated ExPLAIND and found its EPK representations to be accurate and its influence scores to be effective in model compression. Our exploratory study on Grokking suggests that alignment and capability reuse are central to learning. This positions ExPLAIND as a useful toolbox of unified attribution for understanding model behavior.

Appendix A Ethical Considerations

Causality, Overinterpretation, and Misleading Explanations.

While ExPLAIND provides rigorous weight-level influence scores, they are inherently statistical and not causal. Misinterpreting these scores as direct causal claims about model behavior could lead to incorrect conclusions or misguided policy decisions. Practitioners and researchers must exercise caution when drawing normative or regulatory inferences from post-hoc explanations. We encourage a critical understanding of what influence scores measure and emphasize the importance of grounding interpretability tools in empirical validation.

Respecting Data Ownership.

Recent investigations have revealed that major AI companies have utilized large-scale datasets containing pirated content, such as Library Genesis (LibGen), to train their models without obtaining permission from the original authors or rights holders. This practice not only infringes upon the intellectual property rights of creators but also raises significant ethical concerns regarding consent and fair compensation. To enabling mechanisms that would inhibit such practices, we need theoretically grounded attribution of training data and model components.

Unequal Access to Computational Resources.

The development and application of computationally intensive interpretability methods, such as ExPLAIND, underscore a significant ethical concern: the disparity in access to necessary computational resources. This "compute divide" disproportionately favors well-funded industry players and elite academic institutions, enabling them to conduct advanced AI research and model auditing. In contrast, smaller institutions and independent researchers often lack the resources to engage in such work, limiting their participation in critical areas like model interpretability and accountability. This imbalance not only hampers diverse contributions to the field but also raises concerns about whose models are scrutinized and whose voices are heard in shaping AI’s future. Addressing this issue requires concerted efforts to democratize access to computational resources, ensuring that the ability to contribute to and critique AI systems is not confined to a privileged few.

Appendix B Broader Impacts

Interpretability for Fairness and Accountability.

Interpretability is a foundational requirement for building machine learning systems that are transparent, trustworthy, and legally accountable. Our framework, ExPLAIND, contributes to this goal by offering explanations that connect model behavior back to training data and model components. This is especially important in high-stakes domains (e.g., healthcare, criminal justice, finance), where decisions made by machine learning models must be auditable and understandable. Transparent systems are essential for identifying and mitigating biases, ensuring compliance with regulatory standards, and enabling meaningful human oversight.

Attribution and Fair Use of Training Data.

As models increasingly rely on diverse and large datasets, understanding the influence of specific training examples becomes essential for fair data use. ExPLAIND enables tracing a model’s learned behavior to particular training inputs, making it possible to attribute influence of specific works or datasets to model behavior. This opens the door for mechanisms that acknowledge, attribute, and compensate the creators of influential data, thus respecting intellectual property rights. In the long term, methods like ours could support fairer data governance, improve licensing transparency, and foster a more ethically grounded model development ecosystem.

Environmental Costs and the Role of Efficient Interpretability.

Training large models, and by extension applying post-hoc interpretability methods like ExPLAIND, comes with significant computational and environmental costs. While our method is computationally expensive — often comparable to a single training run — we argue that this cost is justified in contexts where theoretical robustness and faithful attribution are necessary. Nonetheless, we acknowledge the environmental impact and advocate for minimizing computational overhead through algorithmic optimization, more efficient implementations and minimizing redundant applications. Future work should investigate scalable approximations of ExPLAIND to reduce emissions while preserving interpretability guarantees.

Appendix C Technical Details and Hyperparameters

C.1 CNN Model

We train a ResNet 9 model with with 5 layers and two residual blocks, each consisting of two additional convolution layers, with maxpooling, ReLU activations and a logarithmic softmax over a two dimensional output. For details, please see the code supplements.

We take the CIFAR2 subset of CIFAR10 consisting of the dog- and cat-classes (10000 samples). We train using SGD with momentum of 0.9 for 12 epochs with a mini-batch size of 256 and weight decay of 0.005. We use a learning rate schedule that peaks in epoch 5 at 0.1. The loss is a cross entropy loss assuming logarithmic probability inputs.

C.2 Transformer Model

The Transformer model, which was proposed by Varma et al. [45] and used by Nanda et al. [31], has a single layer encoder as described by Vaswani et al. [46] and a decoder that consists of a single, fully connected layer mapping from the hidden dimension of 64 to the 115-token vocabulary. We use a 115-token input embedding without positional encodings, followed by a multi-head attention layer with four heads, each mapping to a space of dimension 16. We refer to the modules mapping to the lower dimensional spaces, that used to compute the attention scores, as attention encoder, and accordingly call the modules reading from the representations after applying attention as attention decoder. The MLP layer on top of that consists of two fully connected layers (linear 1 and linear 2), which map to and read from a 512-dimensional latent space.

We train this model on full batches using AdamW a fixed learning rate of 0.001, weight decay of 4.0, and β1=0.98subscript𝛽10.98\beta_{1}=0.98italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.98, β2=0.99subscript𝛽20.99\beta_{2}=0.99italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.99 for the scaling parameters of the first and second moment estimates of the gradient respectively.

The dataset consists of 4000 samples which each contain four tokens, namely the number [a], an addition token [+], the number [b] and the token [mod 113 =]. Here, a,b∈{0,1,…,112}𝑎𝑏01…112a,b\in\{0,1,...,112\}italic_a , italic_b ∈ { 0 , 1 , … , 112 } and we always enforce a≥b𝑎𝑏a\geq bitalic_a ≥ italic_b, leading to a total number of 113⋅1122=6328⋅11311226328\frac{113\cdot 112}{2}=6328divide start_ARG 113 ⋅ 112 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = 6328 possible datapoints of which we include 4000 randomly sampled ones in the train set and another 2000 in the test set labelled with the correct output token [c] containing the correct result c=(a+b)mod113𝑐modulo𝑎𝑏113c=(a+b)\mod 113italic_c = ( italic_a + italic_b ) roman_mod 113 which has to be predicted.

C.3 Compute resources used in our experiments

Model training and retraining were carried out on a 20GB partition of Nvidia A100 GPU for a total of less than 5 hours. Applying ExPLAIND to both models was much more compute intense resulting in about 20 hours of computation on a H200 GPU with 140GB GPU-RAM. Debugging and running the ablations presented, we carried out 12 such full runs of the EPK predictions computing ExPLAIND influence scores bringing the total to about 240 H200 GPU-hours.
